questions.question: Cancer-'The emperor of all maladies spares no one'. Which of the following is the mostcommon childhood malignancy?
You are asked to review an article titled, 'Childhood cancers- a menace'. Which of thefollowing statements is wrong and needs to be edited out?

options.A: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia is the most common type of leukemia in children with Downsyndrome.
options.B: The most common intra-abdominal malignancy is Wilm's tumor.
options.C: The most common extracranial solid malignancy is neuroblastoma.
options.D: The most common brain tumors in children are infratentorial.

questions.explanation: The most common intraabdominal malignancy in children is neuroblastoma.• The most common leukemias seen in Down's syndrome: acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)> acute myeloid leukemia (AML)• The most common site of a brain tumor in children: Infratentorium• The most common extra-cranial solid neoplasm in children: Neuroblastoma• The most common intra-abdominal neoplasm in children: Neuroblastoma• The most common primary neoplasm of renal tissue in children: Wilm's tumor649

questions.question: What is the most common leukemia you would encounter in a child with the followingfindings?640
questions.explanation: The image shows a typical Down's facies (flattened nose, flat occiput, low set ears, protrudingtongue). The most common leukemia in children with Down syndrome is acute lymphoblasticleukemia (ALL).Children with Down syndrome are at increased risk of both acute lymphoid leukemia (ALL) andacute myeloid leukemia (AML).10% of neonates with Down's syndrome develop transient leukemia or myeloproliferativedisorder. These features usually resolve within the first 3 months of life. However, they requireclose follow-up, because 20-30% will develop typical leukemia (often acute megakaryocyticleukemia) by 3 years of life.Note:••Most common leukemia in Down's syndrome: B-cell Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (overall)The most common leukemia in children <3years of age with Down syndrome is acute myeloidleukemia (AML).• Most common AML in Down's syndrome: M7/megakaryoblastic

questions.question: Jeevit, a 7-year-old boy brought to you by his mother, complains of bone pain so severe thathe cannot sleep. Investigations reveal:
questions.explanation: B-lymphoblastic leukemia (pre-B-ALL) is the most common immunophenotype with TdT+, HLADR+, CD10+, CD19+, CD20+, CD24+, Cy Ig +, with onset at 1-10 years of age.The most common type of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) in children is B-lymphoblasticleukemia (previously termed pre-B-ALL)Based on current WHO classification: The most common subtype of ALL is B lymphoblasticleukemia > T lymphoblastic leukemia > Mature B-cell Leukemia (Burkitt leukemia)The production of symptoms and signs of ALL is a result of the replacement of bone marrow bymalignant cells and caused by secondary bone marrow failure. On physical examination, findingsof pallor, listlessness, purpuric/petechial skin lesions, or mucous membrane hemorrhage canreflect bone marrow failure. The proliferative nature of the disease may be manifested aslymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, or, less often, hepatomegaly. At presentation 75% of patientshave leukocyte counts of <20,000/µL; thrombocytopenia is seen in 75% of patients andhepatosplenomegaly in 30-40% of patients. Patients with joint pain may have evidence of jointswelling and effusion. Deep bone pain may be present with marrow involvement, but tendernesswill not be elicited.

questions.question: You are posted in the pediatric hematology department as a first-year postgraduate. All of thefollowing cases you encounter are at an increased risk of developing leukemias except:
questions.explanation: 650Fanconi's anemia (not syndrome) predisposes to the development of childhood leukemias eg:B-ALL due to defective DNA repair. Fanconi syndrome is a syndrome of inadequate reabsorptionin the proximal renal tubules. Congenital pernicious anemia does not predispose to leukemias.Factors predisposing to childhood leukemias•Genetic conditions:• Fanconi's anemia• Bloom syndrome• Ataxia telangiectasia• Li-Fraumeni syndrome• Down syndrome• Severe combined immunodeficiency• Neurofibromatosis 1•Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria• Diamond-Blackfan anemia•Schwachman diamond syndrome• Kostmann syndrome• Environmental factors:•Ionizing radiation• Alkylating agents•• Nitrosoureas⚫ Epipodophyllotoxin• Benzene exposure• Advanced maternal age.

questions.question: To diagnose a 5-year-old child with acute lymphoblastic leukemia, a pathologist has to see atleast percentage of blast cells in a bone marrow biopsy.
questions.explanation: The lower cut-off percentage for diagnosing acute lymphoblastic leukemia on bone marrow biopsyis 25%.Unlike with myeloid leukemias, there is no agreed-upon lower limit for the proportion of blastsrequired to establish a diagnosis of lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). In general, the diagnosisshould be avoided when there are < 20% blasts.The image below shows numerous lymphoblasts seen on a peripheral smear.651Work-up of ALL:It is important that all studies necessary to confirm a diagnosis and adequately classify the type ofleukemia be performed, including bone marrow aspiration and biopsy, flow cytometry,cytogenetics, and molecular studies. The initial evaluation should also include a CSF examination.If lymphoblasts are found and the CSF leukocyte count is elevated, overt CNS or meningealleukemia is present. This finding reflects a poorer stage and indicates the need for additional CNSand systemic therapies.

questions.question: A 4-year-old child who was being evaluated for pancytopenia is diagnosed with acutelymphoblastic leukemia. Which of the following findings would indicate a poor prognosis?

options.A: Minimal residual disease>0.01% at the end of induction therapy

questions.explanation: MRD(Minimal residual disease) is a quantitative estimate of the burden of leukemic cells presentin marrow. MRD>0.01%at the end of induction suggests a poorer prognosis.Initial WBC count of <50,000cells/mm3, B-cell immunophenotype and t(12,21) indicate astandard risk(Favourable prognosis)Risk-directed therapy is the standard of current ALL treatment and accounts for:•Age at diagnosis• Initial WBC count•• Immunophenotypic and cytogenetic characteristics of blast populationsThe rapidity of early treatment response (i.e., how quickly the leukemic cells can be cleared fromthe marrow or peripheral blood)• Assessment of MRD at the end of induction therapy.

questions.question: A 14-year-old boy is rushed to the casualty due to difficulty in breathing and swelling of theface and neck. Clinically, he has features suggestive of superior vena cava obstruction. ChestX-ray image shows superior mediastinal widening. Which of the following is the most likelydiagnosis?
questions.explanation: 652T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) is the most likely diagnosis since the chest X-rayshows superior mediastinal widening- indicating an involvement of the thymus gland.T-ALL accounts for about 15% of childhood ALL cases; it is more common in adolescents - this isthe time when the thymus reaches maximum size.60% of patients with T-ALL present with a mediastinal mass. The mediastinal mass may beasymptomatic and detected only on chest x-ray or may cause cough and dyspnea, particularly onlying flat or with facial swelling and plethora due to vascular compression (superior vena cavasyndrome).B-ALL presents usually between 1-10 years of age perhaps because the number of normal bonemarrow pre-B-cells (the cell of origin) is greatest very early in life.

questions.question: A 2-month-old infant with seizures and failure to thrive has cutaneous nodules andhepatosplenomegaly. On investigations, CBC reveals hyperleukocytosis with a leukocyte countof 1,10,000cells/mm3. Peripheral smear and immunophenotyping studies reveal large,642irregular lymphoblasts, with a phenotype negative for the CD10 (common ALL antigen)marker. On a cytogenetic study which of the following is most likely to be seen?
questions.explanation: The above findings are diagnostic of Infantile acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Translocation (4;11)involving the MLL gene is most commonly associated with Infantile leukemia accounts for thevery high relapse rate.2% of cases of leukemia during childhood occur before the age of 1 year and are referred to asinfantile leukemia.Patients often present with hyperleukocytosis and extensive tissue infiltration producingorganomegaly. Subcutaneous nodules, known as leukemia cutis, caused by infiltration byleukemic cells are observed more often in infants than in older children.The leukemic cell morphology is usually that of large, irregular lymphoblasts, with a phenotypenegative for the CD10 (common ALL antigen) marker (pro-B), unlike most older children withB-ALL, who are CD10 +. Has a very poor prognosis.Note:Infants with AML present with CNS and skin involvement and most commonly have a subtypeknown as acute myelomonocytic leukemia.

questions.question: A mother has noticed recently that her child refuses to be touched, seems to be in distress,and cries inconsolably. She brings her child to you who was investigated thoroughly and wasdiagnosed to have acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Which of the following drugs can be used totreat her?
questions.explanation: L-asparaginase is used in the treatment of acute lymphoid leukaemia (ALL). ALL can present withhepatosplenomegaly, severe joint and bone pains that the kid refuses to be handled.It is observed that some lymphoid malignancies are unable to synthesize asparagine on their ownand must derive it from the bloodstream. L-asparaginase catalyses circulating L-asparagine,thereby inhibiting protein synthesis in the cancer cells.Treatment of ALL•Induction: 4 weeks• L-asparaginase: single dose (side effects: pancreatitis, thrombosis)• Vincristine: weekly (side effects: neuropathy, SIADH)653• Prednisolone• Anthracycline••••• CNS prophylaxis- intrathecal methotrexateConsolidation:Methotrexate⚫ Epipodophyllotoxin••CyclophosphamideCytosine-Arabinoside• Maintenance: 24-36 months• 6-Mercaptopurine• MethotrexateOther options:•Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor used to treat chronic myeloid leukemia and acutelymphoblastic leukemia with t(9;22) BCR-ABL fusion gene.•• Tretinoin is used in acute promyelocytic leukaemia with t(15;17) PML-RARA fusion gene.Cladribine is used in hairy cell leukaemia.

questions.question: You are posted in the hematology department as a pathologist. You are asked to report thebone marrow biopsy slide given below, which belongs to a 3-year-old child who is beingevaluated for pancytopenia. To make a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia, what percentageof such cells should you visualize at the least?643
questions.explanation: Diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is confirmed by the presence of more than 20%myeloblast cells (as shown in the image) in the bone marrow.Flow cytometry and special stains can be used to identify myeloperoxidase-containing cells, whichconfirms the myelogenous origin of leukemia.Note:The diagnosis of acute lymphoid leukemia (ALL) requires the presence of more than 25% blasts inthe bone marrow.

questions.question: A 3-year-old boy was brought to the pediatric OPD with complaints of persistent fever for thepast 1 week. His CBC is given below:
questions.explanation: Monosomy 7 is associated with a poor prognosis in patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).The production of symptoms and signs of AML is a result of the replacement of bone marrow bymalignant cells and caused by secondary bone marrow failure-pallor, fatigue, exercise intolerance,bruising, oral mucosal bleeding, or epistaxis, as well as fever, which may be caused by infection orthe disease.In addition, patients with AML present with signs and symptoms that are uncommon in Acutelymphoblastic leukemia, including subcutaneous nodules or“blueberry muffin" lesions (especially654in infants), infiltration of the gingiva (especially in monocytic subtypes), signs and laboratoryfindings of disseminated intravascular coagulation (especially indicative of acute promyelocyticleukemia), and discrete masses, known as chloromas or granulocytic sarcomas.Prognostic implications of chromosomal abnormalities in AML are given below:Favorable prognosist(8;21); RUNX1-RUNX1T1Inv(16) or t(16;16); CBFẞNPM1mutationCEBPAmutationPoor prognosisinv(3)t(6;9)5q-del(7q)complex karyotype (≥3 abnormalities)Monosomy7

questions.question: A child with a violaceous, raised nodular skin lesion which on biopsy is found to be infiltratedby myeloblasts is likely suffering from which type of Acute myeloid leukemia (AML)?
questions.explanation: Nodular, violaceous skin lesion infiltrated with myeloblasts is descriptive of Chloroma otherwiseknown as extramedullary myeloblastoma or granulocytic (myeloid) sarcoma. Myeloid sarcomas areseen in AML subtypes M2, M4, M5a, and M5b."Chloroma” was coined due to the peculiar green color of the tumor caused by myeloperoxidasepresent in tumor cells.These masses can occur in the absence of apparent bone marrow involvement and typically areassociated with t(8;21) translocation. Chloromas also may be seen in the orbit and epidural space.

questions.question: Erythemic myelosis is
questions.explanation: Erythemic myelosis is AML M6.Constitute about 1% of AML casesTwo subtypes of AML M6:• Erythroid or myeloid leukemia: M6a (more common)•Pure erythroid leukemia: M6b, also called erythemic myelosis (Di Guglielmo disease).

questions.question: A neonate with trisomy 21 has anemia, petechiae, hepatosplenomegaly, and nolife-threatening complications on examination.CBC reveals high leucocyte count andperipheral smear shows numerous myeloblasts. The genetic makeup of blast cells whenstudied reveals GATA-1 mutations. At 3 months of age, his CBC counts come back to normaland there are no blast cells in his peripheral smear. As his treating physician, what would yourecommend?
questions.explanation: This infant has a transient myeloproliferative disease, which usually resolves spontaneously in thefirst 3 months of life, and they require close-follow up because 20-30% will develop typicalleukemia (acute megakaryocytic leukemia) by 3 years of life.655Approximately 10% of neonates with Down syndrome develop transient leukemia ormyeloproliferative disorder characterized by high leukocyte counts, blast cells in the peripheralblood, and associated anemia, thrombocytopenia, and hepatosplenomegaly. These featuresusually resolve within the first 3 months of life. Although these neonates can require temporarytransfusion support, they do not require chemotherapy unless there is evidence of life-threateningcomplications.As only 20-30% of such children develop acute megakaryocytic leukemia a bone marrowtransplant would be a drastic step in our case.

questions.question: An 18-month-old child presents to the pediatric OPD with complaints of fever and rashes forthe past 1 week after extensive workup gets diagnosed as Juvenile chronic myeloid leukemia.Which of the following findings is not consistent with this baby's diagnosis?

options.A: The genetic study may reveal NF-1 mutation
options.B: The presence of Philadelphia chromosome on FISH
options.C: The bone marrow shows a myelodysplastic pattern with <20% blasts.
options.D: The peripheral smear reveals nucleated RBCs

questions.explanation: Patients with juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia do not have the Philadelphia chromosome.Formerly termed juvenile chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), it is a clonal proliferation ofhematopoietic stem cells that typically affects children younger than 2 years of age. Patients withJMML present with rashes, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and hemorrhagic manifestations.Patients with this disease do not have the Philadelphia chromosome (the Philadelphiachromosome is characteristic of CML). The peripheral blood smear shows an elevated leukocytecount with increased monocytes, thrombocytopenia, and anemia with the presence oferythroblasts. Bone marrow shows a myelodysplastic pattern, with blasts accounting for <20%of cells. Patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 and Noonan syndrome have a predilection for thistype of leukemia.JMML in the setting of Noonan syndrome is unique, with most patients having a spontaneousresolution.

questions.question: The most common non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in children is645
questions.explanation: Burkitt lymphoma is the most common non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in children under the age of 15years.Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma(NHL) in adults and adolescents (15-19) years, worldwide.B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL) is the most common childhood malignancy and themost common leukemia in children. (It is not a non-Hodgkin's lymphoma).

questions.question: Which of the following statements best describe the behavior of Non-Hodgkin lymphoma in a10-year-old child?

options.B: Is of high grade and aggressive

questions.explanation: In contrast to adult non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL), which is typically indolent, pediatric NHL isusually high-grade and aggressive.NHL in the pediatric age group has distinct clinical and behavior properties when compared toadults. These include the following:656NHL in adultsNHL in childrenLow/intermediate grade High gradeDominantly nodalVariable growth fractionPoor long-term outcomeExtra-nodalHigh growth fractionGood outcome

questions.question: A 6-year-old boy is brought with complaints of abdominal distension, fatigue, and nightsweats for the past 4 months. He also has a 2-month history of postprandial fullness andrecurrent non-bilious vomiting. On examination, he is pale, has hepatosplenomegaly andshifting dullness. A CT scan shows mesenteric and retroperitoneal lymph node enlargement.A biopsy specimen of the mesenteric lymph node reveals tumor cells with high mitotic indexand starry sky pattern. The cytogenetic study revealed t(8;14). To stage the disease, which ofthe following systems would you use?
questions.explanation: Retroperitoneal and mesenteric lymphadenopathy with hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, and shortduration of disease, point towards a diagnosis of lymphoid neoplasms. The classic translocation oft(8;14) and starry sky appearance with a high mitotic index on HPE point toward a diagnosis ofBurkitt lymphoma. Burkitt's lymphoma is the most common type of Non-Hodgkin lymphomaworldwide. St Jude system of staging is used for staging childhood non-Hodgkin lymphoma.The current revised staging system used for NHL is the International Pediatric Non-HodgkinLymphoma Staging System (IPNHLSS) which reflects our increasing ability to diagnose lowerlevels of organ involvement with disease. For instance, the older staging system (St. Jude/Murphyclassification) did not account for molecular or flow cytometry involvement of bone marrow,which is now reflected in the new system.DiseaseHodgkin lymphomaNon-Hodgkin LymphomaChronic lymphoid leukemiaSystem of stagingAnn Arbor stagingSt Jude(Murphy) stagingRai stagingBinet staging

questions.question: A lymph node biopsy of a 9-year-old child with cervical lymphadenopathy showed thefollowing picture. The diagnosis is646
questions.explanation: In the picture given above, Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells are seen, which is a pathognomonic featureof Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL).Reed-Sternberg cells are large and either multinucleated or have a bilobed nucleus (thusresembling an "owl's eye" appearance) with prominent eosinophilic inclusion-like nucleoli. The RScell is clonal in origin and arises from the germinal center B cells but typically has lost most B-cellgene expression and function.Hodgkin lymphoma encompasses a group of lymphoid neoplasms that typically arise in a signalnode or chain of nodes and spread first to anatomically contiguous sites.WHO classification of Hodgkin lymphoma includes 5 subtypes namely;657• Nodular sclerosis• Mixed cellularity•Lymphocyte-rich• Lymphocyte depletion• Nodular lymphocyte predominanceHistology of lymph node showingReed-Sternberg cell (Owl's eye appearance)OMARROW

questions.question: A 12-year-old female comes to you with a flu-like illness and left supraclavicular swelling ofuncertain nature. Her chest X-ray shows left mediastinal enlargement. CT scan of the chestand abdomen reveals the presence of enlarged lymph nodes in the neck, mediastinum, andliver, and an FDG-PET/CT scan shows multiple scattered consolidation lesions involving alsothe bones. The diagnosis of classical Hodgkin's lymphoma, nodular sclerosis subtype, is madeon cervical lymph node biopsy. According to Ann-Arbor's staging system, how will you stageher disease?
questions.explanation: The clinical vignette describes Hodgkin's lymphoma with the involvement of liver and bonemarrow, which is classified as Stage 4 according to Ann-Arbor staging.Ann Arbor Staging of Hodgkin's LymphomaStage IStage IIStage IIIInvolvement of asinglelymphnode (I) or Lymphoid structure(eg: spleen, thymus, Waldyer's ring)Involvement of 2 or more lymph node regions on thesame side of the diaphragmInvolvement of lymph node regions or lymphoid structures on both sides of thediaphragm (III)658Stage IStage IVABEInvolvement of asinglelymphnode (I) or Lymphoid structure(eg: spleen, thymus, Waldyer's ring)Involvement of extranodal site beyond that designated asE'More than one extranodaldeposit at any locationAny involvement of liver or bone marrowNo symptomsThe presence of fever >38°C (100.4°F) for 3 consecutive daysRecurrent drenching nightsweats Unexplained loss of >10% of body weight in the 6 monthsLocalized, solitary involvement of extra lymphatic tissue, excluding liver and bone marrOW

questions.question: The following parameter in ALL indicate a poor prognosis
questions.explanation: Age >10 years indicates a poor prognosis in ALL.Leukocyte count <50,000/mm3, hyperdiploidy, and trisomy of chromosomes 4,10,17 indicate agood prognosis.

questions.question: Sanctuary sites of acute lymphoblastic leukemia are
questions.explanation: Both CNS and testis are considered as sanctuary sites of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).• A sanctuary site is an area of the body that is poorly penetrated by pharmacological agents and,therefore, serves as a place in which tumor cells or infectious organisms can escape the effects ofdrug therapy.• Early institution of CNS prophylaxis (intrathecal methotrexate) is essential to eradicate theseescaped leukemic cells.• Testicular involvement is rarely evident at diagnosis, testicular involvement can present aspainless testicular enlargement.

questions.question: A 4-year-old boy presents with pancytopenia and hepatosplenomegaly. Bony tenderness isalso present. He is most likely suffering from the following type of ALL
questions.explanation: 659B-cell lymphoblastic leukemia (L1)• This is the most common immunophenotype of acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) in a childbetween the ages of 1-10 years.• They present with features of bone marrow failure and organ infiltration such as pancytopeniaand hepatosplenomegaly, respectively, so B-cell ALL is the most likely diagnosis.•Bony tenderness may be present due to sub-periosteal infiltration of lymphoblastic cells.• T-cell ALL (L2) typically presents in adolescent boys with a large anterior mediastinal mass(thymus or mediastinal lymph nodes), causing respiratory distress or superior vena cavaobstruction.660
